results.title: Forward a century
results.creator_credit: J.B. Napier-Bell, Stuart Legg and Basic Films
results.brief_description: A film made for the Festival of Britain surveying the nation’s achievements during the past 100 years, a note on contemporary conditions, and some indication of possible advances within the next 100 years. Old prints and engravings of life in Victorian ships, financial exchanges and Parliament, customs of the different classes, slums and other manifestations of poverty, all seen against a commentary explaining features of the period’s social, industrial, scientific and political history. Changes since that time illustrated by views of the 1951 Festival and of accomplishments in various technological fields, with emphasis on the increasing concern for human welfare. A number of scientists suggest possible sources of energy and power in 2051.

results.title: The Fortune in the forests
results.brief_description: Portrays the Swedish lumber industry, which in the 1950’s played a vital part in Sweden’s economy. Near the end of winter, power saws fell thousands of trees. The logs are hauled by tractor to the nearest river bank. In spring the logs are bulldozed into the melting rivers, and commence their journey in the fast flowing waters to the timbermills which cluster around the river mouths. Here they are sorted and graded by skilled lumberjacks, hauled into mills, and cut into timber for an endless variety of uses. In Sweden trees are a crop, and care is taken to prevent bushfires and indiscriminate felling. The forests of Sweden are a heritage from the past-they must be replanted and guarded from danger so that they may continue to be a source of wealth to future generations. Story by Albert Viksen; photographed by Sven Olsson; narrated by Burnett Anderson.

results.title: Forster and Lawrence
results.creator_credit: Alasdair Clayre and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 19th Century Novel”.
Richard Hoggart discusses with Graham Martin the contrast between the prose style of D.H. Lawrence and E.M. Forster, with particular reference to the “Fox” and “Where Angels Fear to Tread”.

results.title: Forms of music: instrumental
results.brief_description: Most of the major forms of instrumental music are presented, using animation. Music of Bach, haydn, Mozart and Beethoven illustrate the historical development of the sonata form, the clasical sonata, the concerto, the symphony, and the tone poem, as well as earlier forms of music.

results.title: Formosa today
results.creator_credit: Gordon Bradley, Associated Television and Rank Organisation Film Productions
results.brief_description: Progress in Formosa (Taiwan) since the arrival of Chiang Kai-Shek, and American post war aid. Rapid development in industry and agriculture, roads and railways, education. With greater prosperity, America’s aid is decreasing, and foreign investment increasing. Poses the questions, whether Chiang Kai-Shek has been successful in presenting Formosa as an alternative to Communism.

results.title: Forming of metals
results.creator_credit: Peter De Normanville, Raymond Spottiswoode and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: Methods of forming metals and the qualities they impart to the finished articles. Pressing, hot and cold rolling, forging, drop forging, forging wagon wheels and seamless tubes, drawing and extrusion. Models and micro graphs show the changes in internal structure brought about by forming and annealing. Photographed by Sidney Beadle, Eric Chamberlain. (Award: Documentary Grand Prix, Brussels, 1958).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter De Normanville, Raymond Spottiswoode and Shell Film Unit

results.title: Forming, feeding and assembly
results.creator_credit: Peter Riding, Humphrey Barron and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Approaching Automation”.
Discusses various means of adapting existing equipment, by adding to it or redesigning it. Much manual work can be cut down by installing timing devices and automatic controls, improving feeding methods and reassessing assembly procedures. Shows new methods of mechanical fastening, including the new adhesives. Stresses need to adhere to International and British Standards.

results.title: Form in the making (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Julian Bates, Donald Douglas and Stockwell College of Education
results.brief_description: Follows the work of sculptor Alan Bransbury as he creates a sculpture of the madonna and child. Sequences of the conception, modeling, casting, delivery, and mounting of the sculpture help clarify the techniques and creative problems involved in producing a major work of sculpture.

results.title: Form for function (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Artists at work in the Gustavberg pottery factory at Gustavberg, Sweden. We see how they design their work, how they find aesthetic and practical solutions to functional problems, and the fact that the way in which the finished article is used determines the design and form of the product. Many fine examples of Swedish pottery are included.

results.title: Form + function (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Erik Wernicke, Hans Ruths and Dido Films
results.brief_description: A series of comparisons between the industrial and domestic designs of the early 1900’s and their 1950-1960’s equivalents, in which form is determined by function. Includes examples of architectural and household appliance designs.
